update.description:
* Surgery to config.bat for setting up cmake with Windows. Updated Cmakelist files to include ign-tranpsort and dependencies.

* Added missing zmq lib path input to cmake.

This pull request also includes changes minor changes in a previous pull request that allowed gazebo to build on Windows.

content.raw: I'm not sure what this does or how it was working before, but shouldn't this be `OGRE_RESOURCE_PATH`? It's missing the U. I was having issues  running gzserver and changing this fixed it
content.html: I'm not sure what this does or how it was working before, but shouldn't this be OGRE_RESOURCE_PATH? It's missing the U. I was having issues running gzserver and changing this fixed it

pull_request.title: Config and cmake fixes for Windows build

pullrequest.title: Config and cmake fixes for Windows build

content.raw: Also worth noting this ign-tranpsort pull request https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/148/update-config-cmake/diff is required in order for the gazebo cmake scripts to correctly locate the zeromq .lib files. Currently it will end up matching the zeromq .dll files and the gazebo linking stage will fail.
content.html: Also worth noting this ign-tranpsort pull request https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/148/update-config-cmake/diff is required in order for the gazebo cmake scripts to correctly locate the zeromq .lib files. Currently it will end up matching the zeromq .dll files and the gazebo linking stage will fail.

pull_request.title: Config and cmake fixes for Windows build

pullrequest.title: Config and cmake fixes for Windows build

content.raw:
I currently still run a bath script to set up the environment for the gazebo exe's but it's a very cut down version. The Windows PATH environment variable is limited to 2048 characters by default and the setenv.bat ended up exceeding that for me. Instead of increasing the PATH limit I just copied a number of the dll's to my execution directory.

I would think a Windows installer would place all the dll's in the program directory with probable exceptions being qt and ogre.
content.html:
I currently still run a bath script to set up the environment for the gazebo exe's but it's a very cut down version. The Windows PATH environment variable is limited to 2048 characters by default and the setenv.bat ended up exceeding that for me. Instead of increasing the PATH limit I just copied a number of the dll's to my execution directory.

I would think a Windows installer would place all the dll's in the program directory with probable exceptions being qt and ogre.

content.raw:
@\_jrivero\_ I've going to approve this PR. However, we need to be sure to update both jenkins and our tutorials. Here's what I can think of that needs to happen:

- Update ogre from 1.8 to 1.9 on jenkins and in windows tutorial
- use ZeroMQ 4.0.4 on jenkins and in tutorial. Aaron and I got them zeromq and cppzmq from http://zeromq.org/distro:microsoft-windows and https://github.com/zeromq/cppzmq

I like assigning tasks. Do we agree on these changes? If so, I can PR to update the tutorial since you're the jenkins wizard
content.html:
@_jrivero_ I've going to approve this PR. However, we need to be sure to update both jenkins and our tutorials. Here's what I can think of that needs to happen:

  • Update ogre from 1.8 to 1.9 on jenkins and in windows tutorial
  • use ZeroMQ 4.0.4 on jenkins and in tutorial. Aaron and I got them zeromq and cppzmq from http://zeromq.org/distro:microsoft-windows and https://github.com/zeromq/cppzmq

I like assigning tasks. Do we agree on these changes? If so, I can PR to update the tutorial since you're the jenkins wizard

content.raw:
You are doubly defining a `std::string`.

Occurance 1: Line 45.
Occurance N: Lines 206, 234, 287, etc.

Choices are:

1. Make this a #define
2. Use a `const std::string` here, and replace the `delim` instances below with `PATH_DELIMITER`.
content.html:
You are doubly defining a std::string.

Occurance 1: Line 45. Occurance N: Lines 206, 234, 287, etc.

Choices are:

  1. Make this a #define
  2. Use a const std::string here, and replace the delim instances below with PATH_DELIMITER.

pull_request.title: Config and cmake fixes for Windows build

pullrequest.title: Config and cmake fixes for Windows build

content.raw:
I'm happy to switch to a define if that's more appropriate for keeping things consistent?

For what it's worth a tiny sample size consensus is defines for C and const declarations for C++ (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5545570/const-string-vs-define).
content.html:
I'm happy to switch to a define if that's more appropriate for keeping things consistent?

For what it's worth a tiny sample size consensus is defines for C and const declarations for C++ (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5545570/const-string-vs-define).

content.raw: Ok I must have got it the wrong way around. Given the volume of warnings from gazebo it's arguably preferable to stick with /W3 since /W4  adds informational warnings (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/thxezb7y.aspx).
content.html: Ok I must have got it the wrong way around. Given the volume of warnings from gazebo it's arguably preferable to stick with /W3 since /W4 adds informational warnings (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/thxezb7y.aspx).

pull_request.title: Config and cmake fixes for Windows build

pullrequest.title: Config and cmake fixes for Windows build

content.raw: I'm in favor of anything that reduces warnings. But I disagree with what you said on W3 versus W4. When I run it as-is, it prints ```cl : Command line warning D9025 : overriding '/W3' with '/W4' ``` So, I think it's actually using W4.
content.html: I'm in favor of anything that reduces warnings. But I disagree with what you said on W3 versus W4. When I run it as-is, it prints cl : Command line warning D9025 : overriding '/W3' with '/W4' So, I think it's actually using W4.

pullrequest.title: Config and cmake fixes for Windows build

content.raw: My rational to use Ogre 1.9.0 was that the link on the Windows instructions page stated that version even though the download is for version 1.8.1. I can vouch that 1.9.0 works fine on Windows and has the added benefit of allowing a few pre-processor checks in the gazebo source that were related to 1.9.0 NOT working on Windows to be removed.
content.html: My rational to use Ogre 1.9.0 was that the link on the Windows instructions page stated that version even though the download is for version 1.8.1. I can vouch that 1.9.0 works fine on Windows and has the added benefit of allowing a few pre-processor checks in the gazebo source that were related to 1.9.0 NOT working on Windows to be removed.
